verb.description: (of a person, animal, or other living organism) grow or develop in a healthy or vigorous way, especially as the result of a particularly favorable environment.
examples: wild plants flourish on the banks of the lake

verb.description: (of a person) wave (something) around to attract the attention of others.
examples: “Happy New Year!” he yelled, flourishing a bottle of whiskey

noun.description: A bold or extravagant gesture or action, made especially to attract the attention of others.
examples: with a flourish, she ushered them inside

noun.description: An instance of suddenly performing or developing in an impressively successful way.
examples: the Bulldogs produced a late second-half flourish

noun.description: A fanfare played by brass instruments.

origin: Middle English: from Old French floriss-, lengthened stem of florir, based on Latin florere, from flos, flor- a flower. The noun senses ornamental curve and florid expression come from an obsolete sense of the verb, adorn (originally with flowers).
